thread.title: Trojans rack up 1st win in major way
thread.title_full: Trojans rack up 1st win in major way

title: Trojans rack up 1st win in major way
text:
Trojans rack up 1st win in major way By Mike Tupa mtupa@examiner-enterprise.com 
Like the persistent kangaroo trying to grab the pointed end of a quarter moon, the Caney Valley High School football team finally seized victory. 
With Hunter Hines throwing for 262 yards and Logan Hunt hauling in two touchdown aerials, the Trojans hopped past the Oklahoma Union Cougars, 38-14, in a District 2A-8 showdown, at Oklahoma Union. 
Both teams had been winless heading into the matchup; the Trojans (1-4, 1-2) now have new life in their quest to return to the playoffs for the first time since 2012. 
In reality, the Trojans’ build-up to victory began the previous week, when they put up more than half-a-hundred points in a 63-54 loss to Commerce. 
“Anytime you score more than 50 points, it’s going to give you a lot of confidence,” said veteran Caney Valley head coach Anthony Fogle. “I think it carried over to this week. The kids all believed that on any play we could score.” 
Caney Valley opened its point-letting on a 60-yard touchdown pass play from Hines to Troy Gagan. 
The Trojans would own the lead the rest of the way. 
“Troy made a good catch and run,” said Fogle. “From then on, our offense pretty much controlled the ball.” 
Hunt scored twice on aerials from Hines, and finished with 73 yards receiving on four catches. 
Cooper Eden also snared a touchdown toss from Hines. Hines also scored Caney Valley’s only rushing touchdown. 
“Right now, we’re kind of running by committee,” said Fogle. 
Zane Calvert gained 32 yards on two carries and Garreth Nichols powered to nine yards on the ground. 
But, the Trojans did most their damage through the friendly skies. 
Although Gagan — who gained 112 yards on 10 receptions — drew some special attention from the Cougar defense, Fogle praised the work of all his receivers. 
“We found other kids that stepped up and made plays,” he said. “I was pretty pleased that we’re not one-dimensional.” 
Brandon Fogle hauled in eight catches, Eden fingered five receptions and Hunt made four snags to broaden the Trojans’ passing threat. 
On the defensive side, the Trojans “stepped up and played the run well,” said Fogle. “We started tackling better this week.” 
Caney Valley also turned to its special teams for a big play — a 42-yard return by Gagan, which set up a short touchdown drive. 
Next up, Caney Valley plays host Thursday to Chelsea, which is coming off a loss to Nowata. 
Caney Valley 38, Oklahoma Union 14 
Caney Valley 6 24 0 8 — 38 
Oklahoma Union 2 0 12 0 — 14 
Caney Valley stats 
Hunter Hines 16-57 (1 TD), Zane Calvert 2-32, Troy Gagan 1 -9, Garreth Nichols 6-9. 
Passing 
Hunter Hines 21-31-0-262. 
Receiving 
Troy Gagan 10-112 (1 TD), Logan Hunt 4-73 (2 TDs), Brandon Fogle 8-32, A.J. Young 1-18, Cooper Eden 5-17 (1 TD). Rules for posting comments
